Functions for Users

Network

class reXplan.network.Network(simulationName)

The network class contains information of the pandapower net dataframe, the fragility curve and hazard event.

Simulation

class reXplan.simulation.Sim(simulationName)

The Sim class contains information of the updated power grid, including the outage schedule of power elements, based on the probability of failure and hazard intensity.

Initialize Functions

For explainatory text see Initialize & Run.

Methodology Return Periods

The random samples of the hazard intensity for the methodology of return periods are selected from the ref_return_period.

reXplan.simulation.Sim.initialize_model_rp(self, network, mc_iteration_factor, ref_return_period, cv=0.1, max_mc_iterations=10000, nStrataSamples=10000, min_intensity=None, max_intensity=None, maxStrata=10)

The initialize_model_rp() function utilizes return periods, which needs to be defined in /file/input/project name/returnPeriods/. It uses the R module StratifiedSampling to divide the total event intensity range into strata to reduce uncertainty and computational load. A number of outage schedules is created for the Monte Carlo analysis per stratum, which are collected and stored in the outage schedule file (montecarlo_database.csv). The schedule holds the equipment status information (in-service, out-of-service, awating repair, etc.) for the simulation timeseries. The number of Monte Carlo iterations is optimized by the R module.

The file is stored at /file/output/project name/.

Parameters

  • network – Class variable with network topology, elements, and their properties.

  • mc_iteration_factor – Number of Monte Carlo iterations per stratum sample. Strata samples are calculated using the StratifiedSampling module of R.

  • ref_return_period – Reference return period for fragility curves. Used to generate samples for the Monte Carlo simulation.

  • cv – Coefficient of variation. Measure of variability of a dataset relative to its mean. Used to control the precision of the Monte Carlo simulation. A smaller value of cv will result in a more precise simulation, but will also increase computational time.

  • max_mc_iterations – Limit of Monte Carlo iterations performed during the simulation.

  • nStrataSamples – Number of intensity samples from return period used for the stratification.

  • min_intensity – Minimum intensity of return periods

  • max_intensity – Maximum intensity of return periods

  • maxStrata – Maximum number of strata samples

Network type

reXplan.network.Network

Mc_iteration_factor type

int

Ref_return_period type

str

Cv type

float

Max_mc_iterations type

int

NStrataSamples type

int

Min_intensity type

float

Max_intensity type

float

Methodology Single Hazard

reXplan.simulation.Sim.initialize_model_sh(self, network, mc_iterations)

The initialize_model_sh() function calculates the probability of failure for the electrical components in the network and applies the Monte Carlo Method to create/update the outage schedule for the Montecarlo Analysis (montecarlo_database.csv). This schedule holds the equipment status information (in-service, out-of-service, awating repair, etc.) for the simulation timeseries. Increasing the number of Monte Carlo iterations reduces uncertainty, but increases computational load.

The file is stored at /file/output/project name/.

Parameters

  • network – Class variable with network topology, elements, and their properties.

  • mc_iterations – Number of Monte Carlo iterations.

Network type

reXplan.network.Network

Mc_iterations type

int

Returns

outages schedule of the network

Return type

pandas.core.frame.DataFrame

Run

Running the optimal power flow -> cost analysis, load flow result

reXplan.simulation.Sim.run(self, network, iterationSet=None, saveOutput=True, time=None, debug=None, **kwargs)

The run() function uses the outage schedule (montecarlo_database.csv), generated using one of the initialize functions. A timeseries OPF is executed for the provided network object and updates engine_database.csv with the OPF results.

The file is stored file/output/project name/, if saveOutput = True.

Parameters

  • network – Contains information about the network topology, elements, and their properties. See Network class.

  • iterationSet – If provided, selected Monte Carlo iterations will be selected. If not provided, all iterations will be executed.

  • saveOutput – Determines whether the output database should be saved to a file (engine_database.csv) or not.

  • time – Specifies the duration of the simulation. If provided, it will override the default simulation time set in the self.time variable. See Time class.

  • run_type –

    (of **kwargs) can utilize different OPF approaches:

    -> dc_opf - pypower (Python)

    -> ac_opf - pypower (Python)

    -> pm_dc_opf - PandaModels (Julia)

    -> pm_ac_opf - PandaModels (Julia)

    PandaModels is recommended, as PandaModels has better convergence properties.

Network type

reXplan.network.Network object

IterationSet type

list

SaveOutput type

bool

Time type

class

Run_type type

string

Hazard

reXplan.hazard.Hazard.hazardFromNC(self, filename)
Parameters

filename – string, filename of the nc file. Must end with .nc and must be in the directory: file/input/project name/hazards/

Initializes the Hazard object using a .nc file

reXplan.hazard.Hazard.hazardFromTrajectory(self, filename, max_intensity, max_radius, sdate, edate, geodata1, geodata2, delta_km, frequency='1H')
Parameters

  • filename – string, filename of the csv file. Must end with .csv and must be in the directory: file/input/project name/hazards/

  • max_intensity – float, the rated intensity used for p.u. values in the trajectory data.

  • max_radius – float, the rated radius used for p.u. values in the trajectory data.

  • sdate – datetime, start time of the hazard event, can be generated using datetime.date(year,month,day)

  • edate – datetime, end time of the hazard event, can be generated using datetime.date(year,month,day)

  • geodata1 – network.Geodata, first corner of the geospactial range covered by the hazard

  • geodata2 – network.Geodata, second corner of the geospactial range covered by the hazard

  • delta_km – float, geospatial resolution of the intensity data in km

  • frequency – string, time intervals, default=’1H’

Initializes the Hazard object using a .csv trajectory file

reXplan.hazard.Hazard.hazardFromStaticInput(self, filename, max_intensity, max_radius, sdate, edate, geodata1, geodata2, delta_km, epicenter_lat, epicenter_lon, frequency='1H', epicenter_radius=1, epicenter_intensity=1)
Parameters

  • filename – string, filename of the csv file. Must end with .csv and must be in the directory: file/input/project name/hazards/

  • max_intensity – float, the rated intensity used for p.u. values in the trajectory data.

  • max_radius – float, the rated radius used for p.u. values in the trajectory data.

  • sdate – datetime, start time of the hazard event, can be generated using datetime.date(year,month,day)

  • edate – datetime, end time of the hazard event, can be generated using datetime.date(year,month,day)

  • geodata1 – network.Geodata, first corner of the geospactial range covered by the hazard

  • geodata2 – network.Geodata, second corner of the geospactial range covered by the hazard

  • delta_km – float, geospatial resolution of the intensity data in km

  • epicenter_lat – float, latitude of the epicenter of the hazard event

  • epicenter_lon – float, longitude of the epicenter of the hazard event

  • frequency – string, time intervals, default=’1H’

  • epicenter_radius – float, radius of the hazard event from the epicenter in p.u., default = 1 p.u.

  • epicenter_intensity – float, intensity of the hazard event at the epicenter in p.u., default = 1 p.u.

Initializes the Hazard object using the inputs provided.
